column7: "summary": "In a class action alleging defendant's violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act of 1970 (FCRA)
column9: through its operation of a \"people search engine
column10: \" which searches a wide spectrum of databases to gather and provide personal information about individuals to a variety of users
column11: including employers wanting to evaluate prospective employees
column12: the Ninth Circuit's reversal of the District Court's dismissal of the complaint
column13: which held that plaintiff had not properly pleaded injury in fact as required by Article II
column15: because the Ninth Circuit failed to consider both aspects of the injury-in-fact requirement
column16: its Article III standing analysis was incomplete."}

column6: "summary": "A district court may award costs to prevailing defendants in Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) cases without finding that the plaintiff brought the case in bad faith and for the purpose of harassment
column7: because 15 U.S.C. section 1692k(a)(3) of the FDCPA
column8: which allows for an award of attorney's fees and costs when a party brings suit in bad faith
column9: is not contrary to and does not displace a district court's discretion to award costs under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(d)(1)
column10: which gives district courts discretion to award costs to prevailing defendants unless a federal statute provides otherwise."}

column6: "summary": "In a challenge to a California law that restricts the sale or rental of violent video games to minors
column8: judgment of the appeals court affirming a district court injunction against enforcement of the law is affirmed where the law does not comport with the First Amendment."}

column6: "summary": "In an attorney's putative class action against the United States seeking damages under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)
column7: as well as under the Little Tucker Act
column8: alleging that the electronic receipt he received when paying his client's federal-court filing fee on Pay.gov included the last four digits of his credit card number and the card's expiration date
column9: in willful violation of the FCRA
column10: the judgment of the Federal Circuit reversing the district court's dismissal of the suit
column11: is vacated and remanded where: 1) the Little Tucker Act does not waive the government's sovereign immunity with respect to FCRA damages actions; and 2) where
column13: a statute contains its own self-executing remedial scheme
column14: only its own text can determine whether Congress unequivocally intended to impose the statute's damages liability on the Federal Government."}

column7: "summary": "State-law claims stemming from the storage and disposal of a car
column9: are not sufficiently connected to a motor carrier's service with respect to the transportation of property to warrant pre- emption under Section 14501(c)(1) of the Federal Aviation Administration Authorization Act
column10: where: 1)  plaintiff's state law Consumer Protection Act and negligence claims are not related to the movement of his car; 2)  plaintiff seeks redress only for conduct occurring after the car ceased moving and was stored; and 3) plaintiff's claims are also unrelated to a \"service\" a motor carrier renders its customers."}

column6: "summary": "Judgment of the appeals court upholding the trial court's refusal to compel arbitration under the Federal Arbitration Act (Act)
column7: 9 U. S. C. section 1 et seq.
column8: is reversed because a court may not issue a blanket refusal to compel arbitration under the Act merely on the grounds that some of the claims could be resolved by the court without arbitration
column10: the appeals court's failure to determine whether the balance of respondents' claims were arbitrable was erroneous."}

column7: "summary": "In a damages action brought in federal district court
column10: violated the Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 (TCPA) by repeatedly using an automatic telephone dialing system or prerecorded or artificial voice to call the plaintiff\u2019s cellular phone without his consent
column11: the dismissal of the complaint for want of subject-matter jurisdiction is reversed
column12: as the claim arose under federal law
column13: and the TCPA's permissive grant of jurisdiction to state courts does not deprive the US district courts of federal-question jurisdiction under 28 USC section 1331."}

column6: "summary": "In a suit by a trade association representing meatpackers and processors to enjoin enforcement of a California statute affecting swine slaughterhouses
column7: judgment of the Ninth Circuit is reversed and the case remanded for entry of an injunction
column8: where the Federal Meat Inspection Act (FMIA) expressly preempts the California statute because the FMIA regulates slaughterhouses\u2019 handling and treatment of nonambulatory pigs from the moment of their delivery through the end of the meat production process
column9: and the California statute endeavors to regulate the same thing

column6: "summary": "In a dispute involving the constitutionality of Vermont's Prescription Confidentiality Law
column7: judgment of the the appeals court striking down the statute as an impermissible regulation of speech is affirmed

column2: "title": "Mississippi ex rel. Hood v. AU Optronics Corp.
column6: "summary": "A suit filed by a State as the sole plaintiff does not constitutes a \"mass action\" under the Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) where it includes a claim for restitution based on injuries suffered by the State's citizens
column8: because the State of Mississippi is the only named plaintiff in the instant action
column9: the case must be remanded to state court."}
